evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence in hist_t3_prefinal for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 that contradicts the communication/coordination breakdown among crew as a root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in hist_t3_prefinal.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: Lack of warnings or verbal communication implies a breakdown in communication/coordination
Crew roles and qualifications imply expected communication responsibilities
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew members during the event
If the crew had explicitly communicated and coordinated to prevent the incident

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates a communication and coordination breakdown among the crew during the pushback, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not communicate concerns when the aircraft passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent and impact of communication lapses; no explicit statements of communication attempts or failures beyond assumptions

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in hist_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: Assuming that lack of warnings and assumptions by crew indicate communication breakdown
Assuming the described behaviors reflect coordination issues among crew
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If crew had explicit protocols followed that ensured safety

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows communication and coordination breakdown among crew: no warnings were given despite the impending collision (H8), the trainee driver assumed the instructor knew best and did not speak up (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions were justified and did not intervene (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in the extent of communication attempts and whether all crew roles had full situational awareness

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in the history was present and observable during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing or not observable during the inspection
If the aircraft or personnel did not have access to or knowledge of the TRP markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The TRP (Tug Release Point) marking was present and described as quite small (H7, H13), indicating the environmental/marking deficiency was observable during the prefinal inspection on 12-25 for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure withstands potential defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal data.

defeaters: Evidence showing any mechanical or control system malfunction or failure during the event
Maintenance or technical reports indicating mechanical issues
Sensor or system data logs showing control anomalies
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence items (H1-H13) mention or describe any mechanical or control failure being present or observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the pushback event. The evidence focuses on human actions, communications, and procedural aspects without indicating mechanical/control failure.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical context.

defeaters: If no formal record or report explicitly documenting the procedural deviation existed in the prefinal historical timeline
If the timeline records were incomplete or inaccessible

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical records (H1-H13) document the procedural deviation during pushback, including the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4), the tug instructor's statements on signals and lack of warnings (H8), and the subsequent notifications and damage (H6), confirming the deviation is documented and available in the historical timeline.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

defeaters: If there was evidence that the TRP marking was clearly visible and unambiguous to all personnel during the pushback
If more effective communication or signaling methods were in place and reliably used
If the headset operator or wingman had actively warned the tug instructor

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows the TRP marking existed and was known to personnel (H7, H11), but the visual signals and marking size were insufficient or not fully effective to prevent the pushback beyond the TRP (H8, H13), indicating some vulnerability to defeaters during the inspection.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of visual signals and personnel awareness; lack of direct evidence on robustness of identification during hist_t3_prefinal inspection

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and operational parameters specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback procedures.

defeaters: Evidence showing the procedural deviation was authorized or consistent with Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback procedures
Documentation or expert testimony confirming the deviation aligns with operational parameters for this aircraft and pushback scenario

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the pushback continued beyond the TRP and hit the blast fence (H4), indicating deviation from standard procedure. The TRP clearance is defined (H7), and the tug instructor acknowledged limitations in signaling to stop (H8). The trainee and headset operator assumed the instructor's actions were correct despite passing the TRP (H10, H12). The TRP size was small (H13), possibly contributing to the deviation. No evidence confirms the deviation aligns with Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA specific pushback procedures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA specific pushback procedures or operational parameters; ambiguity about whether deviation was intentional or procedural

node.statement: There is no evidence in hist_t3_prefinal for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 that contradicts the communication/coordination breakdown among crew as a root cause.

assumptions: The provided history items are complete regarding communication events
No other evidence outside hist_t3_prefinal contradicts communication/coordination breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit communication failures or warnings ignored by crew
If logs or recordings indicated miscommunication or lack of coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1, H8, H10, H12) shows that communication among crew and ground personnel was ongoing and no warnings or contradictions to the pushback actions were given, supporting no evidence contradicting communication/coordination breakdown as a root cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit statements about communication breakdown; possible unreported informal communications

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are physically present and installed in the aircraft
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft to verify the presence and installation of all mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from physical damage or wear that would prevent operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform a detailed inspection and maintenance check for damage, corrosion, or wear on mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to the control interfaces
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control components and pilot interfaces through physical inspection and functional testing

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components operate smoothly without obstruction or binding
children_spec.test_procedure: Conduct operational tests to confirm that mechanical controls move freely and respond correctly without sticking or binding

node.statement: Mechanical control components operate smoothly without obstruction or binding

defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical control components binding or obstruction would change the assessment
Evidence that the pushback continued due to human error rather than mechanical failure

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier, indicating some control issue or failure to stop, but no direct mention of mechanical control components binding or obstructing. The continued movement despite engine at idle suggests possible control failure but could also be procedural or human error (H4, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence about the mechanical control components' smooth operation or obstruction; ambiguity whether the failure was mechanical or procedural.

children_spec.statement: Crew members failed to effectively share critical information during the flight
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recorder transcripts and communication logs to identify missed or unclear information exchanges

children_spec.statement: Crew did not coordinate their actions in response to emerging flight issues
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze flight data and crew actions timeline to detect lack of synchronized responses or conflicting actions

children_spec.statement: Crew members resisted or failed to acknowledge input or warnings from other crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine cockpit voice recordings and crew interviews for evidence of ignored or dismissed communications

node.statement: Crew members failed to effectively share critical information during the flight

assumptions: The crew members mentioned constitute the relevant 'crew' for communication during pushback
Lack of verbal warnings or challenges implies ineffective communication
defeaters: If there was evidence of explicit communication or warnings given and acknowledged among crew members about the TRP and pushback status
If the crew had clear protocols and followed them for communication that were documented and verified

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) failed to effectively share critical information or warnings about the pushback passing the TRP, as shown in H8, H10, and H12.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent of communication protocols and whether informal communication was sufficient or expected

node.statement: Crew members resisted or failed to acknowledge input or warnings from other crew members

assumptions: Silence or lack of warning is interpreted as failure to acknowledge input
defeaters: Explicit statements or reports of crew members actively resisting or ignoring warnings
Evidence of direct communication attempts that were ignored or rejected

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that crew members (trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) did not actively warn or challenge the tug instructor despite the pushback continuing past the TRP (H8, H10, H12). However, this appears more as passive assumption or lack of intervention rather than explicit resistance or failure to acknowledge input. Thus, evidence indirectly supports some lack of communication but not clear resistance.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit evidence of resistance or failure to acknowledge; ambiguity whether silence equals resistance

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible in the operational area
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the operational area for presence and visibility of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained in a condition that ensures their availability during operations
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess the condition of environmental markings for wear, damage, or obstruction that would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are not obscured or removed during the relevant operational timeframe
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify that no temporary or permanent obstructions or removals have occurred during the operational timeframe

node.statement: Environmental markings are not obscured or removed during the relevant operational timeframe

defeaters: Direct evidence that markings were obscured or removed during the timeframe
Statements from personnel indicating inability to see markings due to obstruction

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence indicates the TRP ground markings exist and are known to personnel (H7, H13), but there is no direct statement that the environmental markings were not obscured or removed during the operational timeframe. The small size of the TRP (H13) might imply difficulty in visibility but does not confirm obscuration or removal.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence about the condition or visibility of environmental markings during the relevant timeframe
